title: World Cup 2026 bidding delayed
desc: The bidding process for the 2026 World Cup is postponed amid allegations surrounding the 2018 and 2022 tournaments.

title: Video row in France right-to-die case
desc: Campaigners fighting a decision to take a paralysed man off life support have sparked controversy in France by releasing a video of him in hospital.

title: Plane crash link to data-wipe error
desc: A military plane crash was probably caused by computer files being accidentally wiped from three of its engines according to investigators.

title: Suicide attack at Egypt temple
desc: Two assailants are killed in an attempted suicide bomb attack at the Temple of Karnak in Luxor one of Egypt's most popular tourist sites police say.

title: Pope creates child abuse tribunal
desc: Pope Francis approves the creation of a tribunal to hear cases of bishops accused of covering up child abuse by paedophile priests.

title: Baby from ovary frozen in childhood
desc: A woman in Belgium is the first in the world to give birth to a baby using transplanted ovarian tissue frozen when she was still a child doctors say.

title: Big band leader James Last dies at 86
desc: German-born composer and big band leader James Last has died his manager says.

title: Obama 'to send more troops to Iraq'
desc: US President Barack Obama is preparing to deploy as many as 500 additional troops to help train Iraqi forces to fight Islamic State US officials say.

title: Germanwings: Victims return home
desc: A cortege carrying the coffins of German schoolchildren killed in the Germanwings plane crash has arrived in their home town.

title: Scientist 'sorry' over girls comment
desc: A Nobel laureate apologises for offence caused by comments he made about the trouble with girls in science - but says he was being honest.

title: Man jailed over forced marriage
desc: A 34-year-old Cardiff man becomes the first person in the UK to be prosecuted under forced marriage laws introduced a year ago.

title: Pakistan 'shameful' hanging condemned
desc: Pakistan executes a man who was 15 when he was sentenced to death for a double murder in 1992 and who rights groups say was tortured into confessing.

title: VIDEO: Could IS influence shatter Gaza truce?
desc: In the past week several rockets have been fired at Israel from Gaza endangering the 10-month-long ceasefire that ended last summer's deadly war.

title: VIDEO: Fifa's Valcke: 'I made no mistake'
desc: Fifa Secretary General Jerome Valcke dismisses allegations linked to a $10 million payment under investigation by the US authorities.

title: VIDEO: S Korea subway scrubbed to fight Mers
desc: An outbreak of the Mers virus has claimed nine lives in South Korea and authorities are taking steps to curb the spread of the disease and reassure the public.

title: VIDEO: Empty shops and divided societies
desc: As negotiations between Greece and its creditors continue many Greeks feel they have reached the limit of what they can pay.

title: VIDEO: Boy 3 introduces himself to the Queen
desc: A young boy took off his top hat and approached the Queen for a handshake at the Epsom Derby.

title: VIDEO: Fusion of Zulu and classical ballet
desc: An unusual mix of Zulu traditions and classical ballet has arrived at Sadler's Wells Theatre with Inala.

title: VIDEO: The Calais 'shantytown' home to 3000
desc: In Calais migrants seeking to reach the UK have reached the French port from camps in Italy and Greece.

title: VIDEO: Life after solitary confinement
desc: After being released from solitary confinement many prisoners find it hard to adjust to life outside of prison

title: Poll finds Europeans wary of Russia confrontation
desc: A new survey suggests reluctance among many European voters to support military action to defend fellow Nato members against a possible attack from Russia the BBC's Bridget Kendall reports.

title: The journey from Bedouin to billionaire
desc: Mohed Altrad was born a poor Syrian Bedouin. His journey to scaffolding billionaire is an extraordinary tale of quiet perseverance.

title: Do Rubio's money troubles matter?
desc: The New York Times reports on presidential candidate Marco Rubio's struggles with personal finances. Does that disqualify him from office or make him more appealing to average Americans?

title: What is behind Pakistan's dramatic rise in executions?
desc: Pakistan is starting to outstrip the world in executions

title: Islamic State: What has happened since the fall of Mosul?
desc: BBC News looks at some of the key events which have shaped the confrontation with Islamic State in the 12 months since the fall of Mosul.

desc: Different farming methods in the EU and US pose huge difficulties for trade deal negotiators the BBC's Laurence Peter reports.

title: Chimps use leaves to drink alcohol
desc: Scientists find evidence of long term and recurrent drinking of an alcoholic plant sap among chimpanzees in the wild.

title: Actress sued for 'staring' at man
desc: Chinese actress Zhao Wei is being sued after a man claims she stared at him too intensely through his TV set.

title: Africa creates biggest trade zone
desc: Africa's largest free-trade zone is to be created covering 26 countries in an area from Cape Town to Cairo after a deal is signed in Egypt.

title: Zara owner profits up on sales surge
desc: Inditex owner of clothing retailers including Zara and Massimo Dutti sees a 28% rise in net profit for the first quarter of 2015.

title: Russian cybersecurity firm hacked
desc: A leading cybersecurity firm Kaspersky Lab says an infamous hacking group breached its systems in an attempt to steal sensitive information.

title: Fake mobile towers 'snoop on public'
desc: Fake mobile towers that scoop up data from passing phones are routinely being used in London an investigation by Sky News suggests.

title: Grey: New Fifty Shades book 'stolen'
desc: A copy of EL James's latest Fifty Shades novel has been stolen ahead of its publish date.

title: Glennie gets presidential approval
desc: Scottish percussionist Dame Evelyn Glennie and US singer-songwriter Emmylou Harris are praised by US president Barack Obama as they receive the Polar Music Prize.

title: 'Blood cells' found in dino fossils
desc: Researchers have discovered what appear to be the remnants of red blood cells and connective tissue in 75 million-year-old dinosaur fossils.

title: Automated cameras record Serengeti life
desc: Hundreds of automated cameras capture day-to-day animal life in the Serengeti of Tanzania.

title: Artificial leg allows patient to feel
desc: Scientists in Austria have created an artificial leg which allows the amputee to feel lifelike sensations from their foot.

title: Stroke patients tricked into health

title: England 'close to perfect' in NZ win

desc: Atletico Madrid manager Diego Simeone has told Spanish media the club are in talks with Juventus striker Carlos Tevez.

desc: In the 1950s 22 Inuit children were taken from their homes in Greenland to be educated in Denmark - now they want official recognition that the experiment did enormous damage.

desc: Most of the score of one of the 20th Century's most popular film tunes Moon River was never written down but a painstaking restoration is about to make its debut in London.

title: Statue's glow-in-the-dark eyes mocked
desc: Controversy over new statue of Bulgaria's 10th-Century ruler.

title: Twins separated with 3D printer help
desc: Doctors in China use a 3D-printed model to prepare for surgery.

title: Kenya bans teachers over sex abuse
desc: Kenya's authorities ban 126 teachers for gross misconduct mostly for sexual abuse of their students.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi arrives in China
desc: Aung San Suu Kyi Myanmar's opposition leader arrives in China for the first time at a time of tension between the two countries.

title: IS marks anniversary of Mosul's fall
desc: Islamic State militants in Mosul mark the first anniversary of their capture of Iraq's second city which sent shockwaves around the world.
